channel.title: 4 Collaboration Mistakes
channel.description:
Yo! I have thought about making this topic for awhile, but I didn‚Äôt think it‚Äôd be appropriate. Now I think it could be very helpful. We have feedback toward the production of each other‚Äôs songs and each other‚Äôs logos, but I believe a discussion about proper manners toward teamwork is also valid.
It‚Äôs VERY important to have a good relationship with the person you‚Äôre collaborating with. Here are 4 mistakes that HINDER the collaboration process.
1. Lack of communication. You can‚Äôt expect someone to read your thoughts. They will almost ALWAYS think a little different than how you would direct the song. Communicating with what you think could work and what they think could work is essential in keeping things flowing.
2. Picking the wrong partner. This one is tough. It‚Äôs hard to know how a person writes a song. You should assume that everyone composes songs differently than you. But more importantly, find yourself a willing collaborator who HAS A SIMILAR TASTE in music. A progressive house producer working with a dubstep/trap producer naturally won‚Äôt have the flow that two deep house producers would. Great minds think alike, right? ;)
3. Being impatient... and showing it. This one is HUGE. This can make or break collab relationships. Listen. The world is still turning outside of Auxy. I‚Äôm sure everyone you know here and beyond uses Auxy as a hobby. You must hold the reality that many people don‚Äôt compose 24/7. People have LOTS more important things to do. Jobs, families, etc. another problem is actually communicating how impatient you are. If you constantly rain down ‚Äúdone yet?‚Äù messages upon them, you really are driving them and others away from collaborating with you again. Just ask a very polite message that communicates to them that you are still invested in the project. A friendly reminder, for a better term. This leads me to my next point:
4. Lack of politeness/manners This one is obvious. No one wants to work with a jerk. Be as polite as possible. We‚Äôre in a forum where most of us have never met. We don‚Äôt know what we shouldn‚Äôt say to one another! Politeness and friendliness goes so far in the project and further influences a collaboration in the future!
Hope I‚Äôve been a help to you all. Every person takes things differently. It‚Äôs a tricky business to communicate complex ideas and direction to a person without ever seeing them, but there is a right way to do it!
I want to open this topic for conversation! Any points I missed? Any you disagree with? (PM me if you wanna argue ;))

item.description:
Every collab I‚Äôve ended up in (some discord users too), no-one has finished the parts I send back, and they seem to forget all about it when I really would like to get it up and posted!

So frustrating when people don‚Äôt follow through.

Read full topic

item.title: 4 Collaboration Mistakes
item.dc:creator: NotMiles
item.description:
When you request a collab from someone, have a project or at least an idea of what to do. Moves things a lot faster and the other person will know what they‚Äôre getting into.

(Andrew Adams already said that, oops)

Read full topic

item.title: 4 Collaboration Mistakes
item.dc:creator: Andrew_Adams
item.description:
Yeah, I suppose there could be a place for that as well, but I think it depends on the situation. For example, If it‚Äôs someone you know really well, or someone that is desperate for a collab, you could maybe get away with a rather simple approach and just starting from scratch. But if some random dude sends a message to Austin Haga and all he says is ‚Äúwana coLLaB?‚Äù chances are he‚Äôs not gonna be head over heels jumping at the opportunity.

Read full topic

item.title: 4 Collaboration Mistakes
item.dc:creator: Stigmo
item.description:
Good point! Doing this can be really helpful.
Though I have to admit that I also like start a collab from scratch, so that you really build the track together. For example by just sending a simple melody back and forth until it‚Äôs right, and start building from there. This way it is a ‚Äòreal‚Äô collab. It is more time consuming though, and therefore probably more difficult as well.
Thoughts anyone?

Read full topic
